text: Which potassium salt is 28.9% chlorine by mass?
How many sulfur atoms are in 3.00 g of iron pyrite, FeS2 (M = 120.0)?

A gas mixture contains 50 mol% H2 and 50 mol% He. 1.00-L samples of this gas mixture are mixed with variable volumes of O2 (at 0 °C and 1 atm). A spark is introduced to allow the mixture to undergo complete combustion. The final volume is measured at 0 °C and 1 atm. Which graph best depicts the final volume as a function of the volume of added O2?
What is the concentration of nitrate ions in 40.0 mL of a 0.25 M solution of copper(II) nitrate?
1.000 g of a transition metal carbonate, MCO3, is heated to produce the metal oxide and 0.383 g of carbon dioxide (M = 44.01). What is the identity of the metal M?

options.D:
Zn
IONS the corresponding space on the answer sheet using a soft, #2 ide to change an answer, erase the unwanted mark very carefully. s for which more than one response has been blackened will not er correctly. It is to your advantage to answer every question.

text: 14.0 mL of 0.53 M barium nitrate solution and 16.0 mL of 0.44 M sodium sulfate solution are mixed. Which ion is LEAST abundant in solution?
Which salt gives a colorless aqueous solution?

100 mL of a 1.0 M solution of hydrochloric acid is gradually added to a stirred mixture containing 0.01 mol calcium hydroxide, 100 mL water, and a small amount of phenolphthalein. What changes are observed? I. The mixture changes from colorless to pink. II. The mixture changes from cloudy to clear.
Below is shown a section of a buret filled with titrant before beginning a titration. What initial volume should be recorded?
Titration with aqueous triiodide solution to a starch endpoint would be LEAST suitable for which determination?

options.A: Analysis of nickel content in a Ni/Co alloy
options.B: Determination of ascorbic acid in a vitamin C tablet
options.C: Measurement of sulfite concentration in a white wine
options.D: Determination of waters of hydration in a sodium thiosulfate sample

text: Which liquid will NOT react with metallic sodium?

The molar enthalpy of solution of a salt that dissolves endothermically in water is measured in a coffee-cup calorimeter by weighing a known amount of distilled water into the cup and measuring its temperature, then adding a known mass of the salt to the water and measuring the temperature after the salt dissolves. If some water is initially present in the cup before the weighed amount of water is added, what is the effect on the experiment?

options.D: The reaction will be calculated to be exothermic even though it is actually endothermic.

text: When liquid water converts to solid ice at 0 °C and 1 atm pressure, which of the following changes takes place?

options.A: Heat flows out of the system.
options.B: The volume of the system decreases.
options.C: The vapor pressure of water increases.

text: Which isomer of C4H8O2 has the greatest solubility in water?
Which compound has the lowest normal boiling point?

A sealed container contains a gaseous sample at 300.0 K consisting of either pure ethane (C2H6), pure neon (Ne), or a mixture of the two. The pressure inside the container at this temperature is 1.00 atm. When the container is cooled to 150.0 K, the pressure is 0.37 atm. What is the composition of the sample? (The vapor pressure of C2H6 at 150 K is 0.10 atm; the critical temperature of Ne is 44 K.)

options.C: A mixture of ethane and neon.
options.D: It cannot be determined from the information given.

text: Which statement about sulfur, whose phase diagram is shown below, is correct?

options.A: Monoclinic sulfur sublimes at 1 atm pressure while rhombic sulfur does not.
options.B: Rhombic sulfur is less dense than monoclinic sulfur.
options.C: At temperatures above 119 °C, monoclinic sulfur cannot exist at equilibrium.
options.D: The conversion of rhombic sulfur to monoclinic sulfur is endothermic.

text: Aluminum crystallizes in a face-centered cubic unit cell with an edge length of 405 pm. What is its density?

A container with 100.0 g of ice at 0 °C is placed in a humid room whose temperature is 40 °C. The ice melts as water vapor condenses into the container. Assuming that all the heat transferred to the container comes from condensation, how much water will have condensed in the container once all the ice is melted and has reached 40 °C? The heat of fusion of ice is 334 J g-1 and the heat of vaporization of water is 2260 J g-(1).

The standard enthalpy of formation of hematite, Fe2O3(s), is –825.5 kJ mol-(1). What is the standard enthalpy of reaction for the reduction of hematite with carbon monoxide to give metallic iron as shown below? CO(g) + 1/2 O2(g) → ∆H°rxn = –283.0 kJ mol-1 CO2(g) Fe2O3(s) + 3 CO(g) → ∆H°rxn = ??? 2 Fe(s) + 3 CO2(g)
Which of the following equations correctly describe the change in internal energy, ΔE, of a reaction taking place in a bomb calorimeter? I. ∆E = q II. ∆E = ∆H – V∆P

Cyclopropane isomerizes exothermically to propene as shown. The C–C single bond in propene has an estimated bond dissociation enthalpy (BDE) of 345 kJ mol-1, while the C=C double bond in propene has a BDE of 611 kJ mol-(1). Assuming that the C–H bonds in propene and cyclopropane all have the same BDE, what is the estimated BDE of a C–C single bond in cyclopropane?

Two reactions have similar ∆H°rxn values (∆H°rxn (1) ≈ ∆H°rxn (2)), but reaction (1) has a much smaller standard entropy change than reaction (2) (∆S°rxn (1) << ∆S°rxn (2)). At 298 K, which statements about these two reactions must be correct? I. Reaction (1) must have a larger equilibrium constant (Keq (1) > Keq (2)). II. Reaction (1) must have a larger Arrhenius prefactor (A(1) > A(2)).

Dichromate ion is reduced by chloride ion according to the equation below. If [Cl–] is decreasing at a rate of 0.37 mol L-1 min-1, how is the concentration of Cr3+(aq) changing? 14 H+(aq) + Cr2O72-(aq) + 6 Cl–(aq) → 2 Cr3+(aq) + 3 Cl2(aq) + 7 H2O(l)
The isotope cobalt-57 has a half-life of 272 d. How long will it take a sample of 57Co to decay to 38% of its original activity?
Which statement best describes the variation of the rate constant of a reaction with temperature?

options.A: The rate constant does not change with temperature because it is an unvarying characteristic of the specific reaction.
options.B: The rate constant typically decreases with increasing temperature because fewer molecules are able to adopt the required orientation at higher temperature.
options.C: The rate constant typically increases with increasing temperature because increasing the temperature increases the fraction of collisions that result in reaction.
options.D: The rate constant typically increases with increasing temperature because most reactions become more favorable as the temperature increases.

text: A mechanism for the reaction of nitric oxide with hydrogen to form water and nitrogen gas is proposed below. What rate law is predicted by this mechanism? 2 NO(g) N2O2(g) fast, unfavorable equilibrium N N2 2O O2 (( gg )) + + ⇄ H H 22 O(g (g) )→ slow, irreversible N2O(g) + H2(g) → fast, irreversible H2O(g) + N2(g)

An irreversible reaction A + B → C is carried out under various conditions, but always with [B]0 >> [A](0). Plots of 1/[A] as a function of time for each reaction are linear, and the slopes of these plots do not depend on the initial concentration of B. What is the rate law for the reaction under these conditions?
The reaction of H2(g) with C2H4(g) to form C2H6(g) is catalyzed by metallic platinum. Which statement most accurately describes the impact of changing the catalyst in this reaction?

options.A: The rate of the reaction would not change if a greater mass of catalyst were used because the platinum is a solid so its concentration is a fixed number.
options.B: The rate of the reaction would increase if more finely divided platinum were used because the reaction depends on the surface area of the catalyst.
options.C: The ∆H° for the reaction would become more negative if a greater mass of catalyst were used because the catalyst adsorbs the reactants exothermically.
options.D: The ∆S° for the reaction would become more negative if more finely divided platinum were used because the catalyst absorbs gas-phase reactants to form ordered surface species.

text: Lead(II) iodide has a solubility product constant of 1.4 × 10^-(8). What is the concentration of I– in a saturated solution of PbI2?

Sodium bicarbonate decomposes at high temperatures according to the following equation: 2 NaHCO3(s) Na2CO3(s) + CO2(g) + H2O(g) At a certain tempera⇆ture, 50.0 g of NaHCO3 is allowed to react in a 3.0 L evacuated vessel. At equilibrium, the total pressure is 6.25 atm, with some of both solids still present. If 100.0 g of NaHCO3 is allowed to react in the same vessel at the same temperature, what will the pressure be at equilibrium?
In a solution prepared by dissolving 0.1 mol NaNO2 in 1.0 L pure water, which species has the lowest concentration?
A saturated solution of which silver salt has the highest concentration of Ag+?

1.000 g of which salt, when titrated with 0.500 M HCl, gives the titration curve shown?

A galvanic cell is constructed under standard conditions using cobalt in cobalt(II) nitrate solution and indium in indium(III) nitrate solution. Which statements about this cell are correct? Half-reaction E°, V Co2+(aq) + 2e– → Co(s) –0.28 In3+(aq) + 3e– → In(s) –0.34 I. The standard cell potential is 0.46 V. II. Indium is the anode.
Molten sodium chloride is electrolyzed for 10.0 minutes with a constant current of 10.0 A. What mass of sodium metal is produced?

The standard reduction potential of oxygen under acidic conditions at 298 K is +1.23 V. What is the standard reduction potential for the four-electron reduction of O2(g) under basic conditions?
Photons of what wavelength of light have an energy of 1.00 × 10^3 kJ mol-1?
In which set are all three species isoelectronic?
Which change in principal quantum number n involves the greatest change in energy?
Which gas-phase ion has the greatest number of unpaired electrons in its ground state?
Which principle restricts the occupancy of an atomic orbital to no more than two electrons?

options.A: The principle of conservation of energy
options.B: The principle of conservation of angular momentum

text: When copper-64 decays by positron emission, what daughter nuclide is formed?
Which molecule has a nonzero dipole moment?
How many π bonds are in cyanogen, NCCN?
In azomethane, H3CNNCH3, what are the molecular geometries around the carbon and nitrogen atoms, respectively?

options.A: Tetrahedral at carbon, bent at nitrogen
options.B: Tetrahedral at carbon, linear at nitrogen
options.C: Square planar at carbon, bent at nitrogen
options.D: Square planar at carbon, linear at nitrogen

text: What is the bond order of O2+?
Which is the best explanation for phosphorus favoring formation of P4 over P2 molecules, while nitrogen forms only N2 molecules?

options.A: Phosphorus-phosphorus π bonds are weaker than nitrogen-nitrogen π bonds.
options.B: Phosphorus can have an expanded octet while nitrogen cannot.
options.C: The nonbonding electrons on phosphorus occupy an unhybridized s orbital while the nonbonding electrons on nitrogen occupy hybrid orbitals.
options.D: The larger size of phosphorus allows the bonding electrons to be closer together.

text: In the octahedral complex Co(NH2CH2CO2)3, each glycinate ion NH2CH2CO2– binds to cobalt through its nitrogen atom and one of its oxygen atoms. How many stereoisomers of Co(NH2CH2CO2)3 are possible?

Which gas is most reactive toward 1-hexene?
Which structure depicts the enantiomer of the diol shown?

options.D: The diol shown is achiral and does not have an enantiomer.
